questions.text: A surgeon transplants a donor kidney into a 45-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease. The upper 1/3 of the ureter of the transplanted kidney is retained and attached to the recipient patient's bladder. However, soon after transplantation, the ureter becomes necrotic. Which of the following arteries is the major source of blood supply to the upper ureter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Renal artery 

The proximal 1/3 of the ureter receives its blood supply from branches of the renal artery For this reason, this portion of the donor ureter is typically viable after renal transplantation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of double vision. He first noticed mild difficulty focusing his eyes about 3 weeks ago and his symptoms have progressively worsened. The patient's other medical problems include metastatic prostate cancer On neurologic examination, he is unable to adduct his left eye, and stimulation of the left comea does not elicit a corneal reflex. A lesion involving which of the following anatomical structures is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Superior orbital fissure 

This patient's diplopia is caused by his inability to adduct his left eye Eye adduction depends on the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and the medial rectus muscle. The oculomotor nerve originates in the oculomotor nucleus of the midbrain, emerges from the anterior midbrain, and enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure. The patient also has loss of the corneal reflex on the left side. The sensory limb of the corneal reflex is mediated by the nasociliary branch of the first division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V,). The motor component of the corneal reflex is carried primarily by the temporal branch of the facial nerve (CN VII). Like the oculomotor nerve, the nasociliary nerve enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure. Thus, a lesion involving the superior orbital fissure would cause the described deficits

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with vague abdominal pain and undergoes CT imaging of the abdomen (see slide below). Which of the following labeled organs is supplied by an artery of the foregut although it is not a foregut derivative?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The spleen is not a gut derivative; it forms from the mesodermal dorsal mesentery. The splenic artery, however, is a branch of the celiac trunk (the primary blood supply of the foregut).

Key:- 

A)    Liver

B)    Kidney

C)    Spleen

D)    Pancreas

questions.text: A 55-year-old history professor had been experiencing increasing pain in his right hand over the last few months. Additionally, he noticed that he was losing strength in his thumb. he asked the physician if his pain might have anything to do with extensive typing on his computer. The doctor ordered x-rays and an MRI-scan. After careful analysis of the radiological results, his doctor referred the man to an orthopedic specialist. The patient MOST likely suffers from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Carpal tunnel syndrome

This patient likely suffers from carpal tunnel syndrome, in which repetitive stresses placed on the tendons crossing the wrist can produce inflammation in the carpal tunnel, leading to compression of the median nerve. Because the median nerve supplies the muscles of the thenar eminence, carpal tunnel syndrome is characterized by atrophy of these muscles. In particular, atrophy of flexor pollicis brevis will result in weakened flexion of the thumb

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a 40-pack-year history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia is diagnosed with severe atherosclerosis. Atherosclerotic occlusion of which of the following arteries would result in insufficient perfusion of the urinary bladder?

questions.text: An experiment in which human brain RNA is analysed via hybridization to a DNA probe. Which of the following best describes the hybridization technique used in this experiment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Northern blotting refers to a process by which RNA (immobilized on a membrane) is probed with a DNA molecule.

A Western blotting refers to a process by which proteins (immobilized on a membrane) are probed with antibodies.

B Southern blotting refers to a process by which DNA (immobilized on a membrane) is probed with a DNA molecule.

D DNA microarray refers to a process by which DNA (immobilized on a solid support) is probed with complementary DNA (cDNA) molecules.

questions.text: A 7 year old child with sun sensitive skin was advised to stay indoors as chances of skin cancers are very high . Upon examination of the boy, significant patches of discolored skin with areas of severe blistering on his face, arms, and neck that are oozing and raw were found . Molecular analysis of the DNA from the boy's skin keratinocytes would reveal an abundance of which of the following types of lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The boy has the genetic condition xeroderma pigmentosum due to a defect in nucleotide excision repair. The most common form of DNA damage resulting from sunlight exposure is the production of thymidine dimers. Nucleotide excision repair recognizes and removes bulky adducts that alter or distort the normal shape of DNA, which includes thymidine dimers.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to a pediatric unit because he fails to gain weight and has become increasingly weak to the point that he can no longer breast-feed. He is the second son of a healthy Caucasian couple, born by normal vaginal delivery after an uneventful pregnancy. Results of routine pediatric investigations after birth were unremarkable. Physical exam reveals mild cyanosis, shallow respiration, moderate hepatomegaly, an unusually large tongue (macroglossia), and generalized muscular flaccidity. Laboratory: normal complete blood count (CBC), electrolytes, glucose, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and creatinine, but creatine kinase (CK) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) are high. Chest X-ray and echocardiogram show extreme cardiomegaly with outflow tract obstruction and congestive heart failure. Muscle and liver biopsy show intracytoplasmic and lysosomal glycogen accumulation. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomes indicates that the acidmaltase enzyme is defective; therefore, this patient has Pompe disease.

questions.text: The metabolic rate is least affected by an increase in the plasma level of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TBG

Patients with elevated or decreased levels of binding proteins (TBG) are typically euthyroid. 

Increase in plasma level of TBG will cause a transient fall in free thyroid. But since the free hormone is responsible for negative feedback. Fall in free T4 increases TSH and TRH causing the free hormone level to be normal. A new equilibrium is reached where the total quantity of thyroid hormones in the blood is elevated but the concentration of free hormones, rate of TSH secretion and metabolic rate are normal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman accidentally falls down a flight of stairs. After the fall, she is found to have partial loss of voluntary movement on the right side of her body and loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side below the midthoracic region. Which of the following is the probable site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Right half of spinal cord in upper thoracic region

Features of Brown- Sequard syndrome (hemisection of the spinal cord):-

•    Loss of pain and temperature of the opposite side below the level of lesion

•    Touch is least affected

•    All other sensations lost on same side

•    Ipsilateral corticospinal signs

•    Below level of lesion- UMN paralysis; at level of lesion- LMN paralysis

Since the patient has loss of pain and temperature on the left side below the midthoracic region and paresis on the right side, the lesion is probably in the right half of spinal cord in upper thoracic region.

choices.text: Explains the increase in heart rate during exercise

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the Starling’s law of the heart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explains the increase in cardiac output that occurs when the venous return is increased

Starling’s law states that more the initial length more is the tension generated but up to a physiological limit beyond which further increase in initial length decreases the tension generated. Increase in venous return increases the diastolic filling of the ventricle. Increase in end diastolic volume increases the initial length of the ventricular muscle fiber increasing the tension generated and stroke volume. Increase in stroke volume increases the cardiac output.

questions.text: Spontaneous respiration ceases after which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Transection of the brain stem at the caudal end of the medulla

Respiratory center is in the medulla. With a transection of the brain stem at the caudal end of the medulla impulses generated in the medulla cannot excite the phrenic nerve nucleus in the cervical spinal cord, resulting in cessation of respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be expected to increase renin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Administration of a drug that blocks the β-adrenergic receptors

JG cells have β1 adrenergic receptors. Increased sympathetic discharge increases the renin secretion from the JG cells. Administration of a drug that blocks the β-adrenergic receptors will decrease renin secretion.

A.    Acetaminophen, undergoes phase I reaction by CYP2E1 enzyme

B.    CYP3A4, 4 indicates family number 

C.    Procainamide undergoes metabolism by acetylation

D.    St john’s wort is the microsomal enzyme inducer

E.    norepinephrine converted into epinephrine by hydrolysis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acetaminophen, undergoes phase I reaction by CYP2E1 enzyme CYP3A4 is family 3, subfamily A, and gene number 4

Procainamide undergoes metabolism by acetylation

St john’s wort is the microsomal enzyme inducer norepinephrine converted into epinephrine by methylation

questions.text:
Regarding dobutamine find out the false statement

A.    Increases release of NE from sympathetic nerve endings,

B.    Has a t 1/2 of about 2 min

C.    Useful in the non-invasive assessment of patients with coronary artery disease

D.    It increases blood pressure without significantly increasing heart rate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Do not appear to result from release of NE from sympathetic nerve endings, and they are not exerted by dopaminergic receptors

Dobutamine has a t 1/2 of about 2 min; the major metabolites are conjugates of dobutamine and 3-O-methyldobutamine. The onset of effect is rapid. Steady-state concentrations generally are achieved within 10 min of initiation of the infusion by calibrated infusion pump

An infusion of dobutamine in combination with echocardiography is useful in the noninvasive assessment of patients with coronary artery disease

Blood pressure and heart rate may increase significantly during dobutamine administration requiring reduction of infusion rate. Patients with history of hypertension may exhibit an exaggerated pressor response more frequently. Because dobutamine facilitates AV conduction, patients with atrial fibrillation are at risk of marked increases in ventricular response rates; digoxin or other measures may be required to prevent this from occurring. Some patients may develop ventricular ectopic activity.

questions.text:
Find out the true and false statement

A.    lumiracoxib is  withdrawn because of the cardiovascular complications

B.    Piroxicam is short acting NSAID 

C.    Nabumetone is the prodrug

D.    IV indomethacin is useful to maintain the patency of  patent ductus arteriosus 

E.    NSAID decrease the actions of lithium
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rofecoxib, valdecoxib, and lumiracoxib were withdrawn worldwide because of the cardiovascular complications caused by suppression of cardioprotective COX-2–derived PGs, especially PGI2 , and the unrestrained effects of endogenous stimuli, such as platelet COX-1–derived TxA2 , on platelet activation, vascular proliferation and remodeling, hypertension, and atherogenesis

PIROXICAM undergoes enterohepatic recirculation. Estimates of the t 1/2 in plasma have been variable; the average is about 50 h

Nabumetone is the prodrug of 6-methoxy-2-naphthylacetic acid. Nabumetone is approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis.

Indomethacin is approved for closure of persistent patent ductus arteriosus in premature infant

Patients taking lithium should be monitored because NSAIDs, including aspirin, reduce the renal excretion of this drug and can lead to toxicity

questions.text: Regarding alosetron, find out the false statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alosetron, a potent antagonist of the 5HT3 receptor, it causes reduction in GI contractility with decreased colonic transit, along with an increase in fluid absorption, e FDA has reapproved this drug under a limited distribution system for women with severe diarrhea-predominant IBS, Alosetron is rapidly absorbed from the GI tract; its duration of action (~10 h) is longer than expected from its t 1/2 of 1.5 h. It is metabolized by hepatic CYPs and is excreted in the urine and feces. . The most serious adverse reactions are constipation and ischemic colitis, and therapy must be discontinued immediately in patients who develop those symptoms. Other adverse reactions include nausea and vomiting, GI discomfort and pain

questions.text: A 55yr old male patient with history of hypertension and angina, is on lisinopril. Atorvastatin & Aspirin.  He was started on a drug X about one month back.  Now he presents with fatigue, muscle pain & his serum creatinine level was raised.  All of the following could be drug X except.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The major adverse effect associated with statin use is myopathy. Myopathy refers to a broad spectrum of muscle complaints, ranging from mild muscle soreness or weakness (myalgia) to life-threatening rhabdomyolysis. The risk of muscle adverse effects increases in proportion to statin dose and plasma concentrations. . Measurements of creatinine kinase are not routinely necessary unless the patient also is taking a drug that enhances the risk of myopathy. Concomitant use of drugs that diminish statin catabolism or interfere with hepatic uptake is associated with increased risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis. The most common statin interactions occur with fibrates, especially gemfibrozil (38%), and with cyclosporine (4%), digoxin (5%), warfarin (4%), macrolide antibiotics (3%), and azole antifungals (1%). Other drugs that increase the risk of statin-induced myopathy include niacin (rare), HIV protease inhibitors, amiodarone, and nefazodone.

questions.text: A 59-year-old female is brought to the causality with fever. skin flushing and an altered level of consciousness. Her blood pressure is 50/20 mmHg and her heart rate is l20/min. lf blood cultures are positive for E. coli, choose the correct structure shown in the image is responsible for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • This woman is suffering from septic shock. Septic shock results from the release of endotoxins into the bloodstream. Regardless of the bacterialsource. most mammals. including humans. experience the same range of toxic, biological effects as a result of these endotoxins.
  • Image shown here is Gram negative cell wall. 
  • Endotoxins are found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria including E . coli, which is composed of lipopolysaccharide (LPS). 
  • LPS is released during destruction of the bacterial cell wall. It can also be released during cell division. LPS is a very long. heat-stable molecule arranged into three regions: 0 antigen. core polysaccharide. and Lipid A. 
  • Lipid A is responsible for the toxic properties of LPS that lead to Gram—negative sepsis and endotoxic septic shock.
  • Lipid A induces shock by activation of macrophages and granulocytes. This activation results in the synthesis of endogenous pyrogens. such aslL—1= prostaglandins. and the inflammatory mediators: tumor necrosis factor—alpha (TNF—alpha} and interferon. These cytokines then induce afebrile response by the action of lL-1 on the hypothalamus: as well as hypotension. increased vascular permeability with third-spacing of fluids:diarrhea,disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy from a rural village is admitted due to fever, sore throat and difficulty breathing. His immunization status cannot be determined due to abscnce of records. Physical examination shows extensive, coalescing, gray pharyngeal exudate and cervical adenopathy. Several days after being admitted to the hospital, he dies of myocarditis and severe heart failure. The presence of which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IgG against circulating proteins

  • This patient with an uncertain vaccination history likely died from diphtheria, a clinical illness caused by toxigenic strains of Corynebacteriumdiphtheriae. 
  • The disease is rare now a days due to widespread vaccination with diphtheria toxoid, but outbreaks often occur in regionswhere vaccination efforts are insufficient.
  • Most cases are transmitted by aerosolized droplets from asymptomatic carriers or infected patients. 
  • Although the pathogen has little capacity for invasion, it generates a potent exotoxin [diphtheria toxin] that irreversibly inhibits protein synthesis through ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2, leading to host cell death and necrosis. 
  • Local effects of the toxin include pharyngitis and laryngotracheitis. often with an extensive coalescing exudate (pseudo membrane). 
  • Absorption of the toxin into the bloodstream results in potentially life-threatening myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Diphtheria can be prevented with the diphtheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) childhood vaccination. which generates neutralizing IgG antibodies against the binding component of the diphtheria exotoxin. 
  • The vaccine inhibits toxin-mediated cell damage and also reduces the competitive advantage of toxigenic strains thereby reducing toxigenic carriage rates within the population.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman is found to have chronic viral hepatitis B on liver biopsy. The presence of which of the following serologic markers is most likely to increase the risk of vertical transmission of the virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HBeAg

Vertical transmission of hepatitis B from pregnant females to the unborn child can occur with active hepatitis B infection.

Typically, such transmission takes place during the passage of the fetus through the birth canal, but transplacental infection can also occur. 

This is especially common in those women who developed acute hepatitis B infection in the third trimester.

The presence of HBeAg (a soluble protein that is a marker of viral replication and increased infectivity] in the mother significantly increases the risk of vertical transmission of the virus. 

Were this woman HBeAg negative, her neonate’s risk of infection would be 20%. If she were HBeAg positive. however. her neonate's risk of infection would be 95%. 

Moreover should the infant become infected. his chance of progression to chronic hepatitis is 90%. Because of this concern, the newborns of all mothers with active hepatitis B are passively immunized at birth with hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG). followed by active immunization with recombinant HBV vaccine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the clinic with a lesion on his penis, He noted a painful ulcer on the right side of the penis 4 days ago and it has progressively increased in size since then. The patient has had no dysuria, hematuria or penile discharge. He is HIV-positive and is sexually active. The patient currently takes no medications. He appears comfortable and is afebrile. On genitourinary examination, there is a 1.5 cm ulceration on the right side of the base of the penis. this lesion is very tender and soft has irregular, ragged borders and is covered with grey exudate. There is no penile discharge. There is a palpable, tender, enlarged inguinal lymph node in the right groin. The examination is otherwise unremarkable. A scraping of the ulcer is performed. Gram smear shown in the image. PCR testing for herpes simplex virus is negative and darkfield microscopy reveals no organisms. Choose the right pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hemophilus ducreyi

  • Clinical description suggestive of Chancroid.
  • It is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, a gram-negative bacterium transmitted through sexual contact. 
  • Typical school of fish or tram track appearance in Gram stain.
  • It presents as one or more deep painful ulcers with ragged borders that are associated with a grey exudate and inguinal lymphadenopathy. 
  • DOC : Azithromycin.

Presence of protein A on the cell wall

questions.text: A 12 old male child is brought to the pediatrics department by his mother because of high fever, irritability and photophobia. He recently underwentventriculoperitoneal shunt placement for congenital hydrocephalus, On physical examination his temperature is 38.30C and passive flexion of the neck results in spontaneous flexion of the hips and knees. Blood cultures grow coagulase-negative Staphylococcus which is sensitive to novobiocin. Which of the following is the most important Virulence mechanism by which this bacterium causes disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Synthesis of an extracellular polysaccharide matrix

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus species which is novobiocin sensitive and a component of normal skin flora,  is one of the most common causes of infections associated with foreign bodies/ implants (including ventriculoperitoneal shunts)
  •  S epidermidis is adept at causing foreign body infections because of its ability to form biofilms.
  • Once introduced into the body. foreign bodies quickly become coated with a layer of host proteins, including fibrinogen and fibronectin. 
  • These proteins then serve as binding sites for S epidermidis. 
  • After attachment occurs, the bacteria multiply and communicate with one another to induce synthesis of an extracellular polysaccharide matrix that encases the bacteria. 
  • The resulting biofilm functions as a barrier to antibiotic penetration and interferes with host defenses: including opsonization, neutrophil migration, and even T lymphocyte activation. 
  • Once mature, these biofilms can disperse individual pathogen seeds  into the bloodstream and surrounding areas. further disseminating the Infection.
  • Definitive treatment of infections caused by biofilm-producing organisms often requires removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: A 3 year—old boy is brought to the clinic due to high fever, nasal discharge, and cough for 3 days. His family recently returned from a vacation in Goa. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing, febrile child. The patient has bilateral conjunctival injection and several small white spots with an erythematous base on his buccal mucosa as shown in the image. A review of the medical record shows parental refusal of preventive health services in favor of a "natural" approach to the child‘s health. Over the next several days. which of the following is most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Maculopapular rash

Measles virus or rubeola. is an enveloped. Non-segmented, negative-sense RNA virus of the Paramyxoviridae family. 

This highly contagious - to infection is transmitted by airborne or person-to-person contact. 

Classically, measles presents with a prodrome of fever. Cough, rhinorrhea and conjunctivitis. 

Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa are a pathognomonic finding and consist of small white, blue or gray specks on an erythematous base. 

These symptoms precede a maculopapular exanthem that starts on the face and spreads down the trunk and extremities.

The parents‘ refusal of preventive medicine also supports a diagnosis of measles as the child likely did not receive the recommended combinedmeasles. mumps. and rubella (MMR) vaccine. This live attenuated vaccine is safe: serious side effects are extremely rare.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. The patient has no known medical problems. He works as an architect and owns a cat. He has no history of tuberculosis. On examination. he is afebrile and has no focal neurological deficits or meningeal signs. An HIV antibody test and aninterferon—gamma release assay test are negative. Chest x—ray is normal. An MRI of the brain reveals a 2.5 centimeters cyst within the left Sylvian fissure that has minimal enhancement and no associated edema suggestive of Neurocysticercosis. Which of the following is the most likely means of acquisition of the infection responsible for this patient‘s findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Exposure to infected stool.

This patient has no underlying immunocompromising conditions had a seizure and is found to have a cystic brain lesion on MRI

This presentation is most consistent with neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium, the pork tapeworm.

Neurocysticercosis - Ingestion of eggs from the stool of tapeworm carriers can lead to cysticercosis (consumption of infected uncooked pork. which contains the larval cysts but not the eggs= can lead to tapeworm infestation [taeniasis] but not cysticercosis). 

Embryos attach to and penetrate the wall of the small intestine and subsequently migrate hematogenously to tissues, including the brain. where they form cysticerci, fluid-filled larval cysts surrounding the invaginated scolex (head of tapeworm with hooklets)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is evaluated for fever, headache, malaise and cough 3 weeks after returning from summer camp. Lung auscultation is unremarkable. Chest x-ray reveals nodular infiltrates. The patient's blood samples are collected for analysis in anticoagulated tubes. which are transported submerged in ice. when taken out several minutes later, turbidity and clumping are noted. Warming the tube to body temperature leads to rapid dissolution of the clumps. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mycoplasma pneumoniae

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection is common in adolescents and usually presents with tracheobronchitis or walking pneumonia. 
  • The pathogen attaches to the respiratory epithelium using surface antigens (l-antigen) that are also present on the plasma membrane of erythrocytes
  • Therefore. patients with M pneumoniae typically develop cross-reactive IgM antibodies that can attach to red blood cells, activate thecomplement system and cause erythrocyte lysis. 
  • These cross—reacting antibodies are called cold agglutinins because they bind to erythrocytes most strongly at temperatures below core body temperature.
  • Testing for cold agglutinins can be done at the bedside by drawing blood into an edetate disodium—containing tube and placing it in a cup of ice. 
  • Removing the tube after several seconds will reveal clumping- agglutination that resolves as the tube warms
  • Cold agglutinins are often asymptomatic, but some patients develop mild intravascular hemolytic anemia that usually resolves after 6-8 weeks
  • Patients who have infectious mononucleosis and certain hematologic malignancies also commonly develop cold agglutinins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician with a 6-month history of cough and fatigue. He also has experienced malaise and weight loss. He does not recall any sick contacts. The patient is a carpenter. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily. Examination shows left lower lobe crackles. HIV testing is negative. Chest x-ray reveals a pulmonary infiltrate in the lower lobe of the left lung. Results from sputum potassium hydroxide preparation are shown in the image. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis, a fungus present in soil and rotten organic matter. 
  • Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungus. meaning it assumes different forms at different temperatures. In the human body {37-40 C), it assumes the yeast form [single cells). 
  • The image shows a typical large yeast with a single. broad-based bud. 
  • The mold form (branching hyphae] predominates in the environment. at average temperatures of 25-30 deg C
  • Infection occurs by inhalation of aerosolized fungus from the environment In about half of immunocompetent individuals. 
  • Blastomycosis may present as a lung infection or cause a flu-like illness (fever, chills, myalgia, headache,  nonproductive cough] or pneumonia (fever, cough, Pleuritic chest pain). 
  • Pulmonary blastomycosis is diagnosed by finding the typical yeast forms. 
  • In immunocompromised patients, blastomycosis can cause disseminated disease. 
  • Patients experience systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats),  lung involvement (cough, dyspnea),  skin lesions (papules, pustules, ulcers, verrucous lesions} and bone pain (caused by lytic lesions).

questions.text: Patients initially presented with symptoms of fevers, chills, cough, and myalgias, however, progressed to significant respiratory distress and hemodynamic compromise. An early case-control study identified exposure to rodent feces as a risk factor for disease, thus a rodent-trapping operation was initiated. The likely source of infection is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hantaviruses can cause Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome, which is an infectious disease characterised by flu-like symptoms. It can progress rapidly to potentially life-threatening breathing problems.  It can also cause hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome.

Being a zoonotic disease, each hantavirus serotype has a specific rodent host species. It can spread to people via the aerosolised virus that is shed in urine, feces, and saliva. It can spread less frequently by a bite from an infected host.

Symptoms of the Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome are fever, Headaches, Muscle aches, Stomach problems, Dizziness and Chills. Late Symptoms can be lungs filling with fluid and shortness of breath.

questions.text: 21 yrs old male patient with a one year history of development of nasal obstruction on the left with intermittent epistaxis in several opportunities, the latest episode of two days, accompanied by clear rhinorrhea, progressive decrease in olfaction, intermittent bilateral hearing loss at three months of development and weight loss of approximately 10 kg in one year. One examination palpation one lymph node of size 3 cm* 2cm at level III. On oral cavity examination palatal palsy was suspected. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

Ref: Read the text below

Sol.

•    Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is a relatively uncommon cancer with an incidence of 0.29 per 100,000 people per year in Japan. 

•    However, there are certain populations in whom the incidence is considerably higher, including native and foreign-born Chinese, Southeast Asians, North Africans, and native people of the Arctic region.

•    Classification of the World Health Organization divides NPC on a pathological basis into three histological subtypes: keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma; nonkeratinizing carcinoma, which can be further divided into differentiated and undifferentiated subtypes; and basaloid squamous cell carcinoma. Undifferentiated nonkeratinizing NPC is the most common type of NPC and is strongly associated with the Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) in practically 100% of cases. 

•    The most common site of origin for NPC is the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, especially the fossa of Rosenmüller, followed by the superior posterior wall. Nearly half of patients complain of nasal symptoms. 

•    Symptoms related to Eustachian tube obstruction, such as serous otitis media, also commonly occur. Headache and cranial nerve involvement are features of more advanced stages. A direct lateral spread of NPC involves the third division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). The perineural spread of the V3 is one of the most common and important routes in the intracranial paracavernous extension of NPC [3].

•    Gadolinium-enhanced, fat-suppressed, T1-weighted MR imaging is very useful in detecting perineural tumor invasion and extracranial lesions

questions.text:
A 2 year old child presents to emergency with high grade fever and respiratory distress. He has drooling of saliva and her mother told he has been refusing feeds since yesterday. On oral examination there was a bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of midline. Xray soft tissue neck lateral view is shown in picture.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute Retropharyngeal abscess.

Ref:Read the text below.

Sol:-

Retropharyngeal Space - Between the buccopharyngeal fascia covering the pharyngeal constrictor  & the prevertebral fascia.

•    Extends from base of skull to bifurcation of trachea.

•    Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2 (spaces of Gilette).

•    Abscess causes U/L bulge on post pharyngeal wall.

Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs.

•    Results of suppuration of retropharyngeal LN.

•    In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngeal wall.

•    C/F :    * Dysphagia & difficulty in breathing (prominent symp).

•    Stridor & croupy cough.

•    Torticollis.

•    Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline).

•    Xray STN lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow.

•    T/t - I & D without GA, antibiotics.

In Severe TR, the atrial pressure during relaxation increases due to the regurgitant jet from the ventricle. This abolishes the ‘x’ descent and converts the JVP waveform into a ‘cv’ pattern. This simulates an arterial pulse waveform; hence, called as verticalization of JVP. (see below image)

questions.text:
A 14yrs boy was brought to Neurology clinic with myoclonic jerks. The boy who had received good grades in Primary school, had difficulty in even passing his 7th standard examination. The parents were stressed with his worsening grades. A recent visit to an ophthalmologist had detected defect in visual acuity. He had no siblings and his vaccination was complete. EEG was performed. 

What is the diagnosis?+
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SSPE also known as Dawson’s encephalitis. EEG shows Rademaker’s complex.

SSPE is a chronic disease due to measles infection. Majority patients are below 15 years of age.  Most common presenting symptom are scholastic backwardness (52.5%) followed by myoclonic seizures (23.5%). Few patients may have cortical blindness, macular degeneration, decreased visual acuity, and optic atrophy. Electroencephalographic (EEG) shows long interval periodic complexes which are diagnostic of the disease. Only 60% patients give a history of measles infection during childhood. Vaccination is not fool proof against development of SSPE.

questions.text: You have just admitted a young man with past h/o seizure disorder who has just witnessed to have a focal seizure. His family’s description is s/o focal seizure involving left half of body. No h/o LOC. He was brought 2 hrs. After symptom onset, currently he is awake, conscious & oriented but power in left UL is 0/5 with rest of neuronal examination WNL.NCCT(Brain) done is WNL. Best course of action at this time is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Reassess in few hours

In the given case patient is suffering with post ictal paralysis following focal seizure -TODD’S PARALYSIS. Todd’s paralysis can be partial or complete. It can persist for 30 minutes to 36 hours, with an average of 15 hours, at which point it resolves completely. It can affect speech and vision too on rare occasions. It is self-recoverable so reassessment is the best action.

Differentiation from Stroke is important as the management is completely different. In this case, the distribution of the weakness and the Normal NCCT excludes stroke.

questions.text: 28-year-old gentleman presented with postural hypotension. He has a history of recurrent loin pain with episodes of hematuria an year back which was investigated and he was diagnosed with nephrocalcinosis. ABG analysis revealed Metabolic Alkalosis with High urinary Chloride levels. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Barrter’s syndrome

It is an AR inhibitory defect of Na+-K+-2Cl- ATPase pump. It typically presents with hypotension in childhood, but mild mutations can present in adults. Postural hypotension is a sensitive sigh of dehydration. There is Metabolic alkalosis due to secondary hyper aldosteronism. Defect in paracellular transport of calcium leads to nephrocalcinosis. Treatment is adequate hydration and trial of NSAIDs to slow progression of disease

questions.text: Following statements about ABG analysis are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:

Modified Allen’s test is a test of Ulnar artery competence. During the arterial sample collection from the radial artery, there is a small risk of thrombosis. This complication can potentially compromise the vascularity of the palmar arch circulation, unless the Ulanar artery alone is competent to maintain the vascularity. Positive test indicated competent ulnar artery and hence is a requisite to proceed with sample collection.

Breathlessness is most common indication for ABG analysis. Suspected ABB defects is lesser common indication for ABG.

•    Paraneoplastic syndromes are classified as metabolic, neuromuscular, connective tissue, dermatologic, and vascular.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with Raynaud’s phenomenon ad hematuria. On examination he has asymmetrical neuropathy. Laboratory test revealed he is Hepatitis B positive. Renal Angiography revealed microaneurysm at the bifurcation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Systemic necrotising vasculitis is the other name for Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) as it causes fibrinoid necrosis of the medium sized arteries. It is the only arteritis to cause haematuria without GN due to rupture of microaneurysms (on Renal angiography). Gonadal artery involvement can mimic acute abdomen. Skin involvement and mono-neuritis multiplex are common associations. It spares the pulmonary circulation though the bronchial arteries maybe affected in 1-2%of the cases.

questions.text: A 55 year old man presents with progressive anorexia, weight loss, diarrhoea, nausea and vomiting, and profound peripheral oedema. Blood tests show evidence of anaemia and hypoalbuminaemia. Upper GI endoscopy shows enlarged, nodular and coarse gastric folds. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Correct Answer (D)

These features are very consistent with Ménétrier’s disease, which is a rare condition of unknown aetiology characterised by excessive production of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-α). As a result, the mucosal folds of the body and fundus are greatly enlarged. Whilst some patients have upper gastrointestinal symptoms, the majority present in middle or old age with protein-losing enteropathy due to exudation from the gastric mucosa. Endoscopy shows enlarged, nodular and coarse folds. Crohn’s disease of the stomach usually presents with deep ulcers. Cronkhite–Canada syndrome may present with generalised gastrointestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, alopecia and onychodystrophy. NSAID gastropathy presents with gastritis, erosions or single/multiple superficial ulcers.

questions.text: Regarding malignant hyperthermia, which of the following statements are true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a pharmacogenetic disease of skeletal muscle induced by exposure to certain anaesthetic agents, such as suxamethonium and all of the halogenated volatile anaesthetic agents. 

•It is inherited as an autosomal dominant condition and caused by loss of normal Ca 2 + homeostasis at some point along the excitation–contraction coupling process on exposure to triggering agents.

•The most likely site is the triadic junction between the T tubule, involving the voltage sensor of the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), and the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR), involving the Ca 2 + efflux channel of the ryanodine receptor (RYR1).

•Clinical diagnosis can be difficult, as the presentation of MH varies. 

•Masseter spasm is a premonitory sign of malignant hyperthermia.

•Sudden and abrupt rise of ETCO2 is the 1st sign of MH.

•Other signs are those of increased metabolism, like tachycardia, dysrhythmias, increased CO 2 production, metabolic acidosis, pyrexia, and DIC. 

•It can be a florid dramatic life-threatening event or have an insidious onset. 

•It rarely develops 2–3 days postoperatively, with massive myoglobinuria and/or renal failure due to severe rhabdomyolysis.

•Treatment consists of supportive management and IV Dantrolene 2.5 mg/kg bolus up to 10 mg/kg every 5 mins followed by an infusion of 1 mg/ kg every 6 hours for 24 to 48 hours.

choices.text: Automatic external defibrillator (AED) which is used for ventricular fibrillation
Automated external defibrillator (AED) which used for ventricular tachycardia
Manual defibrillator which is used for ventricular fibrillation
Automated external decompressor (AED) which is used for ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image and its correct use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

AED stands for Automated External Defibrillator

•    Public access defibrillation, which places AEDs in the hands of trained laypersons, has the potential to be the single greatest advance in the treatment of VF cardiac arrest since the development of CPR.

•    Time to defibrillation is the most important determinant of survival from cardiac arrest.

•    Survival rates after VF cardiac arrest decrease approximately 7% to 10% with every minute that defibrillation is delayed

•    The automated external defibrillator (AED) is an electronic medical device. 

•    An AED can check a person’s heart rhythm. It can recognize a rhythm that requires a shock. And it can advise the rescuer when a shock is needed. 

•    The AED uses voice prompts, lights and text messages to tell the rescuer the steps to take. 

•    AEDs are very accurate and easy to use. With training, anyone can learn to operate an AED safely.

•    Children over age 8 can be treated with a standard AED. 

•    For children ages 1–8, the AHA recommends the paediatric attenuated pads that are purchased separately. 

•    In infants < 1 years of age a manual defibrillator is preferred.

Steps of using an AED: 

Step 1: POWER ON the AED

Step 2: Attach electrode pads

•    Place the electrode pads on the upper-right sternal border (directly below the clavicle) and lateral to the left nipple, with the top margin of the pad a few inches (approximately 7 cm) below the axilla (Fig). 

•    The correct position of the electrode pads is often illustrated on the pads themselves or another part of the AED. 

•    Stop CPR just before attaching the pads.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient is anesthetized for resection of a temporal lobe tumour. Preoperatively, he is lethargic and confused. After induction of general anesthesia, which of the following would be the MOST appropriate drug to control systemic arterial blood pressure during direct laryngoscopy and tracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Except propofol, all the drugs listed are potent cerebral vasodilators capable of further increasing ICP, which would be highly undesirable in this patient. 

•    Propofol is a potent cerebral vasoconstrictor that will decrease the ICP.

•    It has rapid onset of action and ultra short duration of action.

•    Rest all the drugs wont be very useful 

•    Ketamine: cerebral vasodilator and sympathomimetic

•    Sodium nitroprusside & Nitrous oxide: cerebral vasodilator

Drugs useful to prevent stress response to laryngoscopy and intubation are lignocaine, opioids, nitroglycerine, calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem and β-blockers such as esmolol have been tried.

questions.text: During Mental Status Examination, Judgement is tested on all of following parameters except?

Rational (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

Judgement

This refers to the ability to differentiate between internal and external reality, plan ahead and show responses appropriate to the situations. Three types of judgement are to be described.

i. Social: this is inferred from historical information and observation of behavior in the ward (vide social manners).

ii. Personal: personal logic about present and future. How do you explain the present and future. How do you explain the present state, what is your plan about future?

choices.text: Grade III : Patient is aware of his illness, but blames it on others or external factors

Grade I : Complete denial of illness

questions.text: All of the following are correct with respect to different grades of insight, except? (AIIMS MAY 19)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(Ref : Kaplan Synopsis 11th edn)

Insight: Degree of personal awareness and understanding of illness has 5 grades (Q) 

•    Grade I : Complete denial of illness 

•    Grade II : Slight awareness of being sick and needing help but denying it at the same time 

•    Grade III : Awareness of being sick but blaming it on others, on external factors, on medical or unknown organic factors 

•    Grade IV: Intellectual insight: Admission of illness and recognition that symptoms or failures in social adjustment are due to irrational feelings or disturbances, without applying that knowledge to future experiences 

•    Grade V: True emotional insight: Emotional awareness of the motives and feelings within, of the underlying meaning of symptoms; does the awareness lead to changes in personality and future behavior; openness to new ideas and concepts about self and the important persons in his or her life.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a part of management of shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fundal pressure

Fundal pressure is contraindicated in a case of shoulder dystocia. Suprapubic pressure is allowed and it is given along with McRobert’s maneuver.

questions.text: Primigravida with 26 weeks of gestation has Hb 10gm% with serum ferritin level 10ng/ml. how much oral iron is to be given to this patient daily?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

120mg

According to Anemia Mukt Bharat guidelines, one IFA pill contains 60 mg elemental iron in it. For treatment of IDA (Hb <11gm%) we need to give 2 IFA pills (120mg).

choices.text: Post-partum tubal ligation should not be done laparoscopically
Tubal ligation decreases the risk of ovarian cancer in future
Tubal ligation is most commonly done at ampulla of fallopian tube
Tubal ligation leads to immediate sterilization with no need to wait for 3 months for occlusion

questions.text: Which one of the following is not true regarding tubal ligation operation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tubal ligation is most commonly done at ampulla of fallopian tube

The most common site of tubal ligation is isthmus which is medial 1/3 and lateral 2/3 of the tube. Other statements are correct.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a contraindication for MIRENA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Breast cancer

Progesterone or estrogenic contraceptives are contraindicated in existing breast cancer patients since there may be a flare up of the disease. Other options given in the question are actually the indications for the use of MIRENA

questions.text: What is present in the following contraception?+
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nonoxynol-9

This is a barrier contraceptive called vaginal sponge. It is non hormonal contraceptive. It contains spermicidal agent called as nonoxynol-9.

questions.text: The urogenital sinus forms the lower 2/3 of vagina in females. In males it gets obliterated due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Androgens

Androgens are responsible for formation of external genitalia, descent of testes, development of Wolffian ducts and fusion of UGS.

questions.text: A 72 years old patient has enterocoele, rectocoele with UV descent of third degrees. Which one of the following is not a part of surgery in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Repairing pubo-vesical fascia

Repairing of pubo vesical fascia is a part of treatment of anterior compartment defect like cystocoele. This patient has no cystocoele so there is no need of anterior colporrhaphy.

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions cause ambiguous genitalia at birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

21-hydroxylase deficiency

21- hydroxylase deficiency leads to cortisol pathway defect causing congenital adrenal hyperplasia. It causes increase in testosterone levels leading to ambiguous genitalia at birth.

In other options, the external genitalia is female.

choices.text: Pulsatile GnRH agonists are given in case of infertility
EPRT is given if patient doesn’t desire fertility.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect regarding treatment of Sheehan’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulsatile GnRH agonists are given in case of infertility

In a case of Sheehan’s syndrome, there is pituitary stalk necrosis due to PPH. It leads to deficiency of pituitary hormones and hence the symptoms. For a case of infertility due to Sheehan’s syndrome, we need to give gonadotropin therapy of FSH and LH. Pulsatile GnRH will not work as pituitary is non-functional.

questions.text: In a normal menstrual cycle of 28 days, LH and FSH peak on which days of cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

DAY 13 AND DAY 13 RESPECTIVELY

LH and FSH peak at the same time, about 12 hours before ovulation. So, the maximum levels are seen on day 13 for both.

questions.text: In a vaginal cytology of ovulatory patient, the maturation index on the day of ovulation will show predominance of which cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Superficial

In periovulatory period, estrogen is predominant and hence superficial cells of vaginal epithelium are maximally seen in vaginal cytology.

Intermediate cells are predominant in later part of the ovulatory cycle when progesterone becomes predominant.

questions.text: Which of the following event in puberty is not dependent on estrogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pubarche

In the events of puberty, pubarche is an androgen dependent condition where there will be development of pubic region with hair growth. Other events given in the option are estrogen dependent.

questions.text: In a patient with WHO category 3 anovulatory disorder causing infertility, the treatment of choice is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ovum donation plus IVF therapy

WHO category 3 anovulatory disorders are hypergonadotropic hypogonadism cases which means there is an ovarian failure. Such cases are to be treated by ovum donation IVF cycles.

choices.text: Repeat PAP after 3 years (routine follow up)

questions.text: A 23 years old nulliparous patient has undergone PAP smear which shows ASC-US. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Repeat PAP after 1 year

ASC-US in less than 25 years of age are to be followed up with annual PAP smear till two NILM reports are achieved. If ASC-US comes again then the patient is labelled as screening positive. In patients of age 25 and more, HPV-DNA reflex testing is best.

questions.text: What is the most common location for spontaneous hypertensive intracranial hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The putamen/external capsule is the most common location for a hypertensive intracranial hemorrhage. They account for nearly 2/3 of all hypertensive hemorrhages. The thalamus is the next most common, responsible for 15-25% of the hypertensive hemorrhages, followed by pons and cerebellum at 10%, and lobar hemorrhages at 5-10%.

Hydatid

T1 Weighted image is a short TR & TE sequence which T2 Weighted images is along TR and TE sequence.

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pan coast tumour, MRI is indicated in it for neurovascular invasion/ branchial plexus involvement. Usually for lung cancer CT is preferred.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with epilepsy since age 2 that is refractory to medical treatment has been followed serially with brain MRI scans, which show progressive atrophy of the left hemisphere. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rassmussen encephalitis, Rasmussen encephalitis, also known as chronic focal encephalitis, is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin, usually affecting one brain hemisphere.

choices.text: Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole
Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV levofloxacin

questions.text: A 17-year-old male with AIDS presents with worsening exertional dyspnea, fever, and a nonproductive cough. His temperature is 102 F, heart rate 120 beats/min, and respiratory rate 19. A physical exam reveals mild crackles and rhonchi bilaterally. A chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. He has no known drug allergies. What is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole

Corticosteroids decrease mortality in patients with severe Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP).

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice, but pentamidine is used for those with sulfa allergy. Levofloxacin does not cover PCP. However, if there are infiltrates, it can be added for possible bacterial pneumonia. Adjunctive corticosteroids can decrease the inflammatory response associated with PCP. Also, they can reduce the decline of oxygenation and reduce the incidence of respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 1-year old boy presents with a persistent cough for the past 5 days. He has had several episodes of pneumonia and upper respiratory infections since he was born. He also has several skin infections. He is in the 10th percentile for weight and 5th percentile for height, but at birth, he was in the 50th percentile. A dihydrorhodamine test is abnormal and peripheral blood smear does not indicate hemolytic anemia. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Deficiency in NADPH oxidase Patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) have an NADPH oxidase deficiency, which makes them susceptible to recurrent infections, typically of the respiratory tract.

At the cellular level, CGD can be diagnosed by measuring the capacity of phagocytic leucocytes to form superoxide or hydrogen peroxide. Neutrophilic granulocytes are usually used to detect NADPH oxidase activation in the cells. NADPH oxidase assays include cytochrome c reduction assay and the nitroblue tetrazolium slide assay, both of which measure superoxide. Other assays exist to measure hydrogen peroxide including the dihydrorhodamine-1,2, 3 (DHR) assay, and the hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) or peroxidase activity assay. An abnormal dihydrorhodamine test is significant for a CGD diagnosis. While clinical history may help indicate the patient’s genetic inheritance pattern, genetic testing is available to identify genetic mutations.

choices.text: Discontinuation of the long-acting beta2 agonist

questions.text: A 12-year-old with perennial aeroallergies has severe persistent asthma which is not well controlled with step 5 therapy with high dose inhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta agonist. Which of the following options should be considered? Choices:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Addition of omalizumab

Omalizumab should be considered in patients with documented perennial aeroallergen sensitivity and moderate to severe asthma which is not well controlled. Omalizumab is an anti IgE monoclonal antibody. Omalizumab is now FDA approved for patients ages 6 years and older. Safety and efficacy in children less than 6 years of age have not been established.

1ml/kg; 1:10,000

Improved HR

Cystic fibrosis

questions.text: A woman with bipolar disorder seeks obstetric care during her second trimester. When obtaining her history, the obstetrician learns that she has been taking lithium daily. Prenatal counseling of this woman should include a discussion that maternal lithium use can lead to what potential teratogenic effect on a fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ebstein’s anomaly

questions.text:
A pregnant woman initially presents for prenatal care at 28 weeks’ gestation. Upon review of her history, she reports systemic hypertension in her past medical history and medication use of captopril throughout her pregnancy. You counsel her on the potential teratogenic effects of captopril.

Of the following, the most likely fetal risk associated with maternal captopril is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Renal tubular dysgenesis

Captopril and other angiotension converting enzyme inhibitors pose the greatest risk to the fetus if exposure occurs in 2nd or 3rd trimester. Teratogenic effects include the following:

•Renal tubular dysgenesis

•Hypoplasia of the skull

•Fetal compression syndrome with limb deformities

•Pulmonary hypoplasia in the setting of oligohydramnios

questions.text:
A male infant is born at 37 2/7 weeks’ gestation to a woman with a history of a seizure disorder. Her seizures have been very difficult to manage, so she remained on antiepileptic medication during this pregnancy. Soon after birth, the pediatrician examines the infant and identifies a small lumbosacral myelomeningocele, hypospadias, and postaxial polydactyly on both hands.

Which medication is most likely to account for these clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Valproate

Overall, the risk of major congenital malformations in pregnant women taking antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) is 4% to 6%, compared to 2% to 3% in the overall population. The risk of malformations is influenced by the gestational timing, the type of medication, and the number of medications required for treatment.

The highest risk for malformations is associated with the use of multiple AEDs in the first trimester, with at least one of the medications being Valproate. Valproate has a dose-dependent risk of major malformations, with neural tube defects occurring in 1% to 2% of exposed infants. Other associated major malformations include cleft palate, hypospadias, craniosynostosis, and polydactyly. The overall prevalence of major birth defects in exposed infants is 9%.

choices.text: Among infants who are depressed at birth, direct suctioning of the trachea is not associated with a reduced incidence of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS).
Among infants who are depressed at birth, direct suctioning of the trachea is not associated with reduced mortality.
Meconium management strategies should be altered based on the consistency of the meconium (i.e., “thin” versus “thick”).
There is no benefit in routine endotracheal intubation with direct suctioning of the trachea in vigorous newborns.
There is no benefit to suctioning the oropharynx at the perineum, prior to the delivery of the shoulders.

questions.text: The NRP recommendations about suctioning of infants delivered with meconium-stained amniotic fluid (MSAF) has changed over the years as new evidence has emerged. Based upon the current published evidence, and most recent NRP guidelines, which of the following statements is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Meconium management strategies should be altered based on the consistency of the meconium (i.e., “thin” versus “thick”).

The management of infants who are delivered through meconium-stained amniotic fluid (MSAF) has changed considerably over the years as new evidence has emerged. For example. historically, all infants had their oropharynx suctioned prior to delivery of the shoulders, and once delivered, all infants were intubated to directly suction the trachea, independent of their clinical condition. However, following publication of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) demonstrating no benefit to these treatment strategies, these practices have been slowly abandoned.  Direct endotracheal suctioning has not been associated with either a reduced incidence of MAS or a reduction in mortality.
